properties.name: High Ridge Route
properties.description:
“Lubbock’s central ridge formed a natural high-ground route between Yellow House Canyon (east) and the playa lake basin (west). 
Early roads, downtown districts, and Texas Tech were placed along this elevated divide to avoid flooding and unstable soils. 
The ridge created a stable spine for growth, shaping the alignment of major streets like Broadway, University Ave, and parts of Quaker Ave.

properties.name: Canyon Corridor Route
properties.description:
Yellow House Canyon is the most significant natural landform in Lubbock and has shaped the city’s urban design for more than a century. The canyon’s natural 
depression guided early settlement patterns, limited some street extensions, and created a natural boundary that influenced how the city expanded eastward. 
Water flow through the draw made the area one of the few reliable ecological zones on the South Plains, leading to the creation of Mackenzie Park, the Canyon Lakes
recreational system, and open-space corridors.Because the canyon floor was difficult to build on, development formed around it rather than through it,
creating curved roads, parklands, and irregular property lines that contrast with the surrounding grid. Today, the canyon functions as both a flood-control system and 
a major landscape feature anchoring trails, golf courses, natural habitats, and cultural sites. Its presence continues to shape zoning decisions, recreational planning,
neighborhood boundaries, and the distribution of green space across central and eastern Lubbock.
